data.title: How people see the N64 in Japan?
data.meta_description: The N64 is one of Nintendo's most divisive consoles currently, since it has some great strenghts but also big weaknesses, one of them was the massive lack...
data.text:
Mar 7, 2021

#1

The N64 is one of Nintendo's most divisive consoles currently, since it has some great strenghts but also big weaknesses, one of them was the massive lack of japanese third party support, the western one was decent, but in Japan most of the companies that gave the NES, SNES and kept giving the Game Boy great games mostly or completely ignored the console, with the exception of Hudson and kind of Konami, and that resulted on the console having a horrible library of JRPG's, Adventure games, Fighting games or Shoot em Ups, which were among the most popular genres in Japan and resulted on the console selling way less copies than the Super Famicom, in fact a huge part of the lost sales from the SNES to the N64 were from Japan only. However even with all those problems the console didn't sell terribly in Japan, with over 5 million units and many of the games by Nintendo or Rare sold pretty well there, which for a console that had so little software appealing for Japanese players (probably even less than the OG Xbox) is surprising, it even sold far more than the Gamecube there which did have more games appealing for them. Probably having exclusive Pokémon games helped at the time

I have seen some threads here asking about things like this and some people seem to know a lot about how japanese players feel about some things (I wouldn't be asking if that wasn't the case), and I would really like to know if people in Japan hate it or consider it an ok console

The CD thing was obviously a problem for the JRPGs, but I don't know why the fighting games and shoot-em-ups couldn't have come out on N64.

Fighting games are easy to explain: the controller wasn't very nice for playing traditional fighting games on, and no arcade stick was made for the system. Some fighting games came out on it but they ranged from mediocre to absolutely awful (War Gods and Clayfighter 63⅓ were notorious stinkers) so people didn't bother bringing their good stuff over when the Playstation already had the Tekkens and Street Fighters cultivating that thriving market.

There is no doubt that in term of software support and variety PS1 was the successor of the Super Famicom.

However I think some underestimate N64 current recognition because their rational consider strictly only what happened 20-25 years ago instead of thinking more broadly about what happened since 20-25 years ago.

The Nintendo franchises created on N64 or that had the first 3D outing on N64 went from strength to strength in Japan without interrupting their line until the current situation that see Nintendo having almost a monopolistic grip on the japanese market, with a lot of the big sellers being from the same franchises popularized on N64.

For instance I have no doubt that an eventual N64 Mini would outsell the PS Classic in Japan.

nope. close to 350k, which, back then, is pretty good. Sakura Taisen 1 needed to sell 200k for it to be considered a massive sales success and it sold just a hair better than Grandia.

on topic: you look at the highest selling games in Japan from this time frame-- RPGs and Fighting games-- and the N64 has very little representation from those genres-- two genres the Playstation 1 and Saturn absolutely murder in. it's not really any surprise it sold even less than the Saturn in Japan, considering the popularity of Virtua Fighter, Darkstalkers and Sakura Wars back in the mid-to-late 90s.
